questions.text: Calculate net filtration pressure with the following data: PGC: 42 mmHg πGC: 12 mmHg; PBC: 16 mmHg Assume that no proteins were filtered.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

14 To calculate the net filtration pressure (NFP), we use the formula: NFP = (PGC - πGC) - PBC where: PGC = Glomerular capillary hydrostatic pressure πGC = Glomerular capillary osmotic pressure (colloid osmotic pressure) PBC = Bowman's capsule hydrostatic pressure Given the data: PGC = 42 mmHg πGC = 12 mmHg PBC = 16 mmHg Now, let's plug in the values: NFP = (42 - 12) - 16 NFP = 30 - 16 NFP = 14 mmHg The net filtration pressure is 14 mmHg. So, the correct answer is: C. 14

Highyeild:

Hydrostatic pressure of the glomerular capillaries (P GC ): It is the only force that promotes filtration. Under normal conditions, this is the main factor that determines GFR. Hydrostatic pressure in Bowman’s space (P BS ): It opposes the filtration. Normally, it is low and fairly constant and does not affect the rate of filtration. However, it increases and reduces filtration whenever there is an obstruction downstream, such as a blocked ureter or urethra (postrenal failure). Oncotic pressure of the plasma (π GC ): It varies with the concentration of plasma proteins. Because fluid is filtered but not protein. It opposes filtration. Protein or oncotic pressure in Bowman’s space (π BS ): There is very little if any protein present, and this factor is mainly considered as zero for all practical purposes. To get net filtration pressure we need to add the filtration opposing pressures (π GC + P BS ) and subtract it from the filtration promoting pressure (P GC ).

questions.text: Which hormones is/are under inhibitory control of hypothalamus?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Both GH and prolactin Both Growth Hormone (GH) and Prolactin are under inhibitory control of the hypothalamus.

Highyeild:

The hypothalamus produces and releases various releasing and inhibiting hormones that regulate the secretion of hormones from the anterior pituitary gland. In the case of GH, the hypothalamus secretes Growth Hormone-Releasing Hormone (GHRH), which stimulates the release of GH from the anterior pituitary. On the other hand, for Prolactin, the hypothalamus secretes Dopamine (also known as Prolactin-Inhibiting Hormone or PIH), which inhibits the release of Prolactin from the anterior pituitary.

Extraedge:

GH under inhibitory control of somatostatin and prolactin under inhibitory control of dopamine from hypothalamus. Prolactin secretion is tonically inhibited by dopamine (prolactin-inhibiting factor [PIF]) secreted by the hypothalamus. Somatomedins are produced when growth hormone acts on target tissues. Somatomedins inhibit the secretion of growth hormone by acting directly on the anterior pituitary and by stimulating the secretion of somatostatin from the hypothalamus. The major hypothalamic releasing hormones are: Thyrotropin releasing hormone (TRH) Corticotropin releasing hormone (CH) Growth hormone releasing hormone (GHRH) Gonadotropin releasing hormone (GnRH) The major hypothalamic inhibitory hormones are: Prolactin inhibitory hormone or dopamine Growth hormone inhibitory hormone (GHIH), also called Somatostatin.

questions.text: Which hormone has permissive role in puberty?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Leptin Leptin is a hormone produced by adipose (fat) cells and is involved in regulating energy balance and body weight. It plays a permissive role in puberty by signaling the hypothalamus about the body's energy stores.

Highyeild:

The adipocyte-derived hormone leptin acts as a permissive factor for the onset of puberty by increasing the pulsatile rate of GnRH secretion acting in the brain. Leptin is secreted by fat cells. It stimulates anorexigenic neurons and inhibits orexigenic neurons, thus decreasing appetite.

Random:

Explanation for other options: - Option: B. GnRH (Gonadotropin-Releasing Hormone) - GnRH is a hormone released by the hypothalamus, and it plays a direct stimulatory role in puberty. GnRH is responsible for initiating the release of luteinizing hormone (LH) and follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) from the pituitary gland. These hormones, in turn, trigger the development of secondary sexual characteristics and the maturation of the reproductive system during puberty. Option: C. Insulin - Insulin is a hormone produced by the pancreas and is primarily involved in regulating blood glucose levels. While insulin plays essential roles in metabolism and energy utilization, it does not have a direct permissive role in puberty. Option: D. GH (Growth Hormone) - Growth Hormone is produced by the pituitary gland and is responsible for growth and development in childhood and adolescence. While GH is involved in growth-related processes, it is not considered to have a permissive role in initiating puberty.

questions.text: The earliest stage at which erythropoietin is effective in red blood cell formation is?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Burst forming units Erythropoietin (EPO) is a hormone produced by the kidneys in response to low oxygen levels in the blood. It plays a crucial role in red blood cell formation, also known as erythropoiesis. The earliest stage at which erythropoietin is effective in red blood cell formation is at the "Burst forming unit" (BFU-E) stage.

Highyeild:

The stages of red blood cell formation are as follows: Hematopoietic stem cell (HSC): The earliest precursor cell that can differentiate into all types of blood cells, including red blood cells. Common myeloid progenitor (CMP): A more specialized cell that gives rise to various myeloid lineage cells, including erythrocyte/megakaryocyte progenitors. Burst forming unit-erythroid (BFU-E): A committed erythroid progenitor that can give rise to a colony forming unit-erythroid (CFU-E). Colony forming unit-erythroid (CFU-E): The next stage that responds to erythropoietin and gives rise to the late erythroblast stage. Late erythroblast stage: This is the stage where cells undergo terminal differentiation to become normoblasts.

Extraedge:

Erythroid burst-forming unit (BFU-E is the most primitive single lineage committed erythroid progenitor population of Erythroid Colony Forming Units (CFU-E). CFU is derived from burst-forming units.

questions.text: Which of the following heart sound may be a normal finding during pregnancy?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

S3 An increased S3 may be heard during late pregnancy. This heart sound is heard in early diastole. During pregnancy, it is common for some changes to occur in the cardiovascular system due to the increased demands on the circulatory system. One of the normal findings during pregnancy is the presence of an S3 heart sound.

Highyeild:

S3 is an extra heart sound that occurs early in diastole, after the S2 heart sound. It is often described as a "ventricular gallop" and can be heard as a low-frequency sound, like a "Kentucky" or "Ken-tuc-ky" sound. The S3 sound is associated with rapid ventricular filling and is often considered normal in pregnant women, especially during the third trimester. This is due to increased blood volume and the increased workload on the heart during pregnancy.

Random:

Explanation for other options: - Option: A. Fixed splitting of S2: This is not a normal finding during pregnancy. Fixed splitting of S2 refers to a consistent delay in the closure of the aortic and pulmonic valves, which can be seen in conditions like atrial septal defect (ASD). Option: C. S4: The S4 heart sound occurs late in diastole and is also known as an "atrial gallop." While it can be found in some healthy individuals, it is not typically considered a normal finding during pregnancy. Option: D. Pericardial knock: This refers to an abnormal sound caused by a sudden cessation of ventricular filling due to pericardial stiffness. It is associated with pericardial constriction and is not a normal finding during pregnancy.

Table:

#MANTRA Cardiovascular changes in pregnancy The resting pulse rate increases by 10 beats/min The apex is moved laterally Cardiac output remains elevated throughout (maximum in the immediate postpartum X-Ray shows a larger cardiac silhouette (due to benign pericardial effusion and shiftec ECG: Slight left axis deviation Heart Sound types :- First heart sound: Loud with an exaggerated split Second heart sound: Normal but loud Third heart sound: Loud and easily heard

questions.text: Which cell organelle is absent in cardiac muscle in the region marked by an arrow in the image?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Lysosome The single nucleus of the cardiac muscle cell is located in the center of the cell. Myofibrils pass around the nucleus, producing a Bi conical juxta nuclear region in which the other organelles are concentrated. This perinuclear region is rich in mitochondria and contains a Golgi apparatus, glycogen granules, and lipofuscin granules. The marking areas are centrally placed nuclei. Note : In a mammalian cell, lysosomes are located near perinuclear region known as “perinuclear cloud.” In cardiac muscle, they are very less in number (not completely absent).

Random:

Explanation for other options: - Option A. Option B. A nerve cell, showing Golgi apparatus Option C.

questions.text: Most effective parameter to decrease blood flow to tissue bed:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Diameter of vessel The most effective parameter to decrease blood flow to a tissue bed is the diameter of the blood vessel that supplies the tissue. This is known as vasoconstriction. When the diameter of the blood vessel decreases, it restricts the flow of blood through that vessel, reducing the amount of blood delivered to the tissue bed.

Highyeild:

Changes in vessel diameter (resistance) are most important quantitatively for regulating blood flow within an organ, as well as for regulating arterial pressure. Changes in vessel diameter, particularly in small arteries and arterioles, enable organs to adjust their own blood flow to meet the metabolic requirements of the tissue.

Random:

Explanation for other options: - Option: B. Venous pressure: An increase in venous pressure can cause venous congestion, but it does not directly reduce blood flow to the tissue bed as effectively as vasoconstriction. Option: C. Arteriole pressure: While the pressure in the arterioles can regulate blood flow, increasing or decreasing arteriole pressure will not have as direct and immediate an impact on reducing blood flow as vasoconstriction. Option: D. Viscosity: Blood viscosity refers to the thickness or stickiness of the blood. An increase in blood viscosity can affect blood flow, but it does not directly target the tissue bed's blood supply as vasoconstriction does.

Solution:

Intensity of stimulus It describes the relationship between the magnitude of a physical stimulus and the perceived intensity or strength of the sensation it produces.

Highyeild:

The Weber–Fechner law refers to two related laws in the field of psychophysics, known as Weber’s law and Fechner’s law. Both laws relate to human perception, more specifically the relation between the actual change in a physical stimulus and the perceived change. This includes stimuli to all senses: vision, hearing, taste, touch, and smell. Weber-Fechner law states that the magnitude of a subjective sensation experienced by the observer increases proportional to the logarithm of the intensity of physical stimulus. The formula for the same is given below. S = K × log I where S = Subjective sensation experienced by the observer (psychological intensity); K = Constant; I = Intensity of physical stimulus.

Random:

Explanation for other options: - Option: A. Number of nerve fibers: The Weber-Fechner law is not directly related to the number of nerve fibers. Instead, it deals with the relationship between the intensity of a physical stimulus and the perceived intensity of the sensation. It is about how the human sensory system perceives changes in stimulus intensity, not the physical characteristics of nerve fibers. Option: B. Number of muscle fibers: The Weber-Fechner law does not have any direct connection to the number of muscle fibers. It is not concerned with muscle physiology but rather with the perception of sensory stimuli and how we perceive changes in their intensity. Option: C. Number of stimulus: The Weber-Fechner law is not related to the number of stimuli. It is focused on the intensity of a single stimulus and how that intensity is perceived by the sensory system. It does not deal with multiple stimuli or their quantity.

Solution:

Increased preciseness of movements "Increased preciseness of movements," signifies the correct interpretation. When a particular area in the motor homunculus is relatively large, it means that there are more cortical resources dedicated to controlling movements of that specific body part. This increased representation implies greater precision and finer motor control for that body region. "Increased preciseness of movements," signifies the correct interpretation. When a particular area in the motor homunculus is relatively large, it means that there are more cortical resources dedicated to controlling movements of that specific body part. This increased representation implies greater precision and finer motor control for that body region. For example, the hand and fingers have a much larger representation compared to the rest of the body in the motor homunculus because they require more precise and skilled movements.

Highyeild:

In homunculus, the size of the various parts is proportionate to the use of the part (skilled fine movement with precision). In homunculus, the largest area represents the face, hand, and fingers where precise localization is most important.

Random:

Explanation for other options: - Option A, "Low control and skilled movements," is not correct. Larger areas in the motor homunculus actually indicate a higher level of control and more skilled movements for the corresponding body parts. Option B, "More muscle fibers are present," is also not correct. The size of the representation in the motor homunculus is related to the complexity of motor control and the number of cortical neurons dedicated to controlling movements, not the number of muscle fibers in the body part.

questions.text: Compliance curve of the lung is given below. What does Curve A signify?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Emphysema Curve “A” has higher TLC and higher compliance than normal curve, which is typical of emphysema. Bronchitis may have high TLC (obstructive disease) but compliance generally remains normal or slightly higher than normal. This is a compliance curve. Left and up in the graph (A) : Indicates increased compliance. Right and down in the graph (B) : Indicates reduced compliance. Hence the answer is emphysema (increased compliance). All the other disorders mentioned have reduced compliance.

Extraedge:

Lung compliance Chest wall compliance Increased lung compliance Lung surfactant Lung volume: compliance is at its highest at FRC Posture (supine, upright) Loss of lung connective tissue associated with age Emphysema Increased chest wall compliance Ehler-Dahlos syndrome and other connective tissue diseases Rib resection Cachexia Flail segment rib fractures Open chest (eg clamshell) Decreased static lung compliance Loss of surfactant (eg. ARDS) Decreased lung elasticity Pulmonary fibrosis Pulmonary oedema Decreased functional lung volume Pneumonectomy or lobectomy Pneumonia Atelectasis Small stature Alveolar derecruitment Alveolar overdistension Decreased dynamic lung compliance Increased airway resistance (eg. asthma) Increased airflow (increased resp rate) Decreased chest wall compliance Structural abnormalities Kyphosis/scoliosis Pectus excavatum Circumferential burns Surgical rib fixation Functional abnormalities Muscle spasm, eg. seizure or tetanus Extrathoracic influences on chest/diaphragmatic excursion Obesity Abdominal compartment syndrome Prone position
